title: PART A: THESIS/CLAIM
stimulusHtml: To earn this point, the thesis must make a claim that responds to the prompt, rather than merely restating or rephrasing the prompt. The thesis must consist of one or more sentences located in one place, either in the introduction or the conclusion.
descriptions: Does not respond to the prompt with a historically defensible thesis/claim that establishes a line of reasoning.

Responds to the prompt with a historically defensible thesis/claim that establishes a line of reasoning about how the process of industrialization brought economic change to Asia in the period 1700â€“1900.

title: PART B: CONTEXTUALIZATION
stimulusHtml:
To earn this point, the response must describe broader historical events, developments, or processes that occur before, during, or continue after the time frame of the question that are relevant to the topic of the prompt. To earn this point, the context provided must be more than a phrase or a reference.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary.
descriptions: Does not describe a broader historical context relevant to the prompt.
Describes a broader historical context relevant to European transoceanic voyages.

title: PART C1: EVIDENCE - PROVIDES EVIDENCE
stimulusHtml:
To earn one point, the response must identify at least two specific pieces of evidence relevant to the topic of the prompt.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary.
descriptions: Does not provide at least two specific historical examples of evidence relevant to the topic of the prompt.
Provides at least two specific historical examples of evidence relevant to the topic of the prompt.

title: PART C2: EVIDENCE - USES EVIDENCE TO SUPPORT AN ARGUMENT
stimulusHtml:
To earn this point, the response must use at least two pieces of specific and relevant evidence to support an argument in response to the prompt.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary.
descriptions: Does not support an argument in response to the prompt using at least two pieces of specific and relevant evidence.
Supports an argument in response to the prompt using at least two pieces of specific and relevant evidence.

title: PART D1: USES HISTORICAL REASONING
stimulusHtml: To earn the point, the response must demonstrate the use of historical reasoning to frame or structure an argument, although the reasoning might be uneven or imbalanced, or the evidence may be overly general or lacking specificity.
descriptions: Does not use historical reasoning (e.g. comparison, causation, CCOT) to frame or structure an argument that addresses the prompt.
Uses historical reasoning (e.g. comparison, causation, CCOT) to frame or structure an argument that addresses the prompt.
